title: Approach to Nonmalignant Leukopenia and Leukocytosis

title.__html: Approach to Nonmalignant Leukopenia and Leukocytosis

children: Approach to Nonmalignant Leukopenia and Leukocytosis

Although leukopenia and leukocytosis may raise concern for an underlying hematologic malignancy, many causes are benign. Variability is expected in blood counts in the general population, with reference ranges spanning two standard deviations around the mean. Normal variation can sometimes explain aberrant leukocyte counts, with 2.5% of persons falling above or below standard reference ranges. Some other common nonmalignant causes of quantitative abnormalities in the leukocyte count are listed in

. The basic elements of evaluation include personal history and physical examination; family history; review of medication, supplements, and other drug use; complete blood count and differential; and peripheral blood smear.

A decreased absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) can occur in response to glucocorticoids, other medications, and various bacterial and viral infections. Chronically low ALC and recurrent infections should prompt evaluation for immunodeficiency and measurement of immunoglobulin levels. Lymphopenia without clinical consequences or an associated illness does not require treatment.

Neutropenia can result from impaired marrow production, immune-mediated destruction, or cellular redistribution, especially to the spleen, as with portal hypertension due to cirrhosis or portal vein thrombosis. Effects depend on the degree of neutropenia, bone marrow reserve, and comorbid conditions. Severe neutropenia is classified as an ANC less than 500 cells/μL (0.5 × 10
Benign ethnic neutropenia (BEN) is a mild, chronically low ANC, typically 1000 to 1500 cells/μL (1-1.5 × 10

/L), although it can be lower. BEN is more common among certain demographics, including those of African descent. Myeloid progenitors are mildly reduced, with a smaller neutrophil reserve in the circulation and bone marrow. However, myeloid maturation and function are normal. BEN does not result in increased frequency or severity of infections or other significant clinical consequences.

Many drugs can cause medication-induced neutropenia, which results from impairment of normal granulopoiesis in the bone marrow or through a drug-dependent, antibody-mediated immune destruction of circulating neutrophils. These effects are typically seen within the first 3 months of drug initiation and are often reversible. Medication-induced neutropenia most often occurs in patients older than 50 years. Symptoms can include fever and oral ulcerations or may be related to sites of infection, with complications more common with lower ANCs. Treatment focuses on removing the offending agent, and symptoms often resolve within 1 to 3 weeks. Granulocyte-colony stimulating factor can shorten recovery time and may be used in patients with neutropenia and active infection.

Nutritional deficiencies can also cause neutropenia. Cobalamin and folate deficiencies can lower the ANC, often with concomitant macrocytic anemia and, at times, thrombocytopenia. Copper deficiency is a rare cause of neutropenia and anemia that responds to copper supplementation.
Autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus can also be associated with isolated neutropenia.
Lymphopenia without clinical consequences or an associated illness does not require treatment.
Benign ethnic neutropenia results in a chronically low absolute neutrophil count but without significant clinical consequences.
Medication-induced neutropenia occurs most often in patients older than 50 years during the first 3 months of drug treatment; symptoms usually improve within 1 to 3 weeks of stopping the medication.

Neutrophilia, lymphocytosis, and monocytosis are often reactive secondary to infection or inflammation. Lymphocytosis occurs with many viral processes. Acute Epstein-Barr virus infection can present with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and elevated ALC; atypical lymphocytes may be mistaken for blasts. Monoclonal B-cell lymphocytosis refers to a monoclonal population of B lymphocytes (<5000/μL [5 × 10

/L]) that does not meet criteria for chronic lymphocytic leukemia or lymphoproliferative malignancy; it is usually detected incidentally in asymptomatic patients. Approximately 1% to 2% of patients with a clone size greater than 2000 cells/μL (2 × 10

/L) evolve to meet criteria for chronic lymphocytic leukemia during each year of follow-up; patients with a smaller clone size have a much lower risk and normal longevity. No intervention is required, but patients should be monitored periodically for signs of progression.

Neutrophilia frequently accompanies bacterial infections and can be caused by certain medications, including glucocorticoids. Cigarette smoking is another common cause, although the mechanism is unknown, and these effects often persist for a prolonged period after smoking cessation—sometimes for years. Obesity, especially in women, may be associated with neutrophilia.

Monocytosis accompanies some infections such as tuberculosis. Persistent monocytosis (for >6 months) without obvious infection, particularly when associated with cytopenias (e.g., anemia or thrombocytopenia), should be referred for evaluation of possible hematopoietic stem cell disorders.
Cigarette smoking is a common cause of chronic neutrophilia; the mechanism is unknown, and neutrophilia may persist for a year or more following smoking cessation.
Monoclonal B-cell lymphocytosis occurs in generally asymptomatic patients who lack other criteria for a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

title.__html: Nonmalignant Causes of Abnormal Leukocyte Counts

children: Nonmalignant Causes of Abnormal Leukocyte Counts
Inherited: Benign ethnic, cyclic, familial, congenital

Medications: Antibiotics (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone, vancomycin), psychiatric (clozapine, tricyclic antidepressants), immunomodulatory (methotrexate, azathioprine, tacrolimus, mycophenolate, others), thyroid (methimazole, propylthiouracil)
Autoimmune: Primary autoimmune neutropenia, secondary to systemic process (SLE, rheumatoid arthritis)
Infections: HIV, hepatitis, tuberculosis, typhoid, malaria, measles, fungal (histoplasmosis)
Systemic disease: Autoimmune (SLE, rheumatoid arthritis), sarcoidosis, Cushing syndrome, aplastic anemia
Other: Alcohol, zinc deficiency, protein-losing enteropathy
Infections: Viral (EBV, CMV, HIV, influenza), bacterial (pertussis, cat scratch disease,
Acute/chronic inflammatory states: Inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatologic disorders
Medications: Lithium, glucocorticoids, myeloid growth factors, catecholamines

footnotes: ALC = absolute leukocyte count; ANC = absolute neutrophil count; CMV = cytomegalovirus; EBV = Epstein-Barr virus; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.
